drugDetails.content:
Preamble

PEP is Post-Exposure Prophylaxis.

It means taking antiretroviral medicines (ART) after being potentially exposed to HIV to prevent becoming infected.

Indications and Usage

PEP should be considered if you’ve had a recent possible exposure to HIV at work.

Report your exposure to your supervisor, and seek medical attention immediately.

Occupational transmission of HIV to health care workers is extremely rare, and the proper use of safety devices and barriers can help minimize the risk of exposure while caring for patients with HIV.

Dosage and Administration

PEP must be started within 72 hours after a recent possible exposure to HIV, but the sooner you start the PEP, the better.

Every hour counts.

If you're prescribed PEP, you'll need to take it once or twice daily for 28 days.

PEP is effective in preventing HIV when administered correctly, but not 100%.

PEP normally consists of three anti-HIV drugs, from two of the different classes.

(A regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred).

TDF + 3TC (or FTC) + EFV as a fixed-dose combination is recommended as the preferred option to initiate ART for adults and adolescents.

Remember to take an HIV test 3 months after exposure.

Pregnant and breastfeeding women can be treated with PEP.

Contraindications

Do not treat pregnant women with Efavirenz or Nevirapin.

Adverse Reactions

HIV treatment can cause side-effects which tend to be the worst when you first start taking them.

If you are taking PEP you may experience some unpleasant side-effects such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, headaches and fatigue.

The drugs used in a course of PEP today are less likely to cause side-effects than those used in the past.

chapters.content:
Using alcohol-based handrub is indicated when hands are visibly clean.

Use alcohol-based handrub before and after every procedure, such as before and after touching a patient, after touching patient's surroundings, before a clean procedure, after body fluid exposure risk and before and after wearing gloves.

Guide to Local Production:

WHO-recommended handrub formulations.

Liquids Required

  • Ethanol 96% OR Isopropyl alcohol 99.8%
  • Hydrogen peroxide 3%
  • Glycerol 98%
  • Sterile distilled OR boiled cold water

Materials Required

  • 10-litre glass or plastic bottles with screw-threaded stoppers, OR
  • 50-litre plastic tanks (preferably in polypropylene or high density polyethylene, translucent so as to see the liquid level), OR
  • Stainless steel tanks with a capacity of 80-100 litres (for mixing without overflowing)
  • Wooden, plastic or metal paddles for mixing
  • Measuring cylinders and measuring jugs
  • Plastic or metal funnel
  • 100 ml plastic bottles with leak-proof tops, OR
  • 500 ml glass or plastic bottles with screwtops.
    An alcoholmeter: the temperature scale is at the bottom and the ethanol concentration (percentage v/v) at the top.

Note:

    Glycerol: used as humectant, but other emollients may be used for skin care, provided that they are cheap, widely available and miscible in the water and alcohol and do not add to toxicity, or promote allergy.
    Hydrogen peroxide: used to inactivate contaminating bacterial spores in the solution and is not an active substance for hand antisepsis.
    Any further additive should be clearly labelled and be non-toxic in case of accidental ingestion.
    A colourant may be added to allow differentiation from other fluids, but should not add to toxicity, promote allergy, or interfere with antimicrobial properties. The addition of perfumes or dyes is not recommended due to risk of allergic reactions

10-litre preparations:

These can be prepared in 10-litre glass or plastic bottles with screw-treaded stoppers.

Recommended amounts of products:

10-litre preparations

Formulation 1

  • Ethanol 96%: 8333 ml
  • Hydrogen peroxide 3%: 417 ml
  • Glycerol 98%: 145 ml
  • Sterile distilled or boiled cold water: 1105 ml

Formulation 2

  • Isopropyl alcohol 99.8%: 7515 ml
  • Hydrogen peroxide 3%: 417 ml
  • Glycerol 98%: 145 ml
  • Sterile distilled or boiled cold water: 1923 ml

Final products:

Formulation 1

Final concentrations:

  • Ethanol 80% (v/v)
  • Glucerol 1.45% (v/v)
  • Hydrogen peroxide 0.125% (v/v)

Formulation 2

Final concentrations:

  • Isopropyl alcohol 75% (v/v)
  • Glycerol 1.45% (v/v)
  • Hydrogen peroxide 0.125% (v/v)

Step by Step Preparation:

1. The alcohol (Ethanol or Isopropyl) for the formula to be used is poured into the large bottle or tank up to the graduated mark.

2. Hydrogen peroxide is added using the measuring cylinder

3. Glycerol is added using a measuring cylinder.

As glycerol is very viscous and sticks to the wall of the measuring cylinder, it should be rinsed with some sterile distilled or cold boiled water and then emptied into the bottle/tank.

4. The bottle/tank is then topped up to the 10-litre mark with sterile distilled or cold boiled water

5. The lid or the screw cap is placed on the tank/bottle as soon as possible after preparation, in order to prevent evaporation.

6. The solution is mixed by shaking gently where appropriate or by using a paddle.

7. Immediately divide up the solution into its final containers (e.g. 500 or 100 ml plastic bottles), and place the bottles in quarantine for 72 hours before use.

This allows time for any spores present in the alcohol or the new/re-used bottles to be destroyed.

1. Pre-production analysis should be made every time an analysis certificate is not available to guarantee the titration of alcohol (i.e. local production).

Verify the alcohol concentration with the alcoholmeter and make the necessary adjustments in volume in the preparation formulation to obtain the final recommended concentration.

2. Post-production analysis is mandatory if either ethanol or an isopropanol solution is used.

Use the alcoholmeter to control the alcohol concentration of the final use solution.

The accepted limits should be fixed to ± 5% of the target concentration (75%–85% for ethanol).

3. The alcoholmeter shown in the image above is for use with ethanol; if used to control an isopropanol solution, a 75% solution will show 77% (± 1%) on the scale at 25°C.

Labelling should be in accordance with national guidelines and should include the following:

  • Name of institution, date of production and batch number.
  • WHO-recommended hand rub formulation.
  • For external use only.
  • Avoid contact with eyes.
  • Keep out of reach of children.
  • Date of production and batch number.
  • Use: Apply a palmful of alcohol-based handrub and cover all surfaces of the hands. Rub hands for 20- 30 seconds.
  • Composition: Ethanol or isopropanol, glycerol and hydrogen peroxide.
  • Flammable: Keep away from flame and heat.

• Production and storage facilities should ideally be air conditioned or cool rooms. No naked flames or smoking should be permitted in these areas.
  • WHO-recommended handrub formulations should not be produced in quantities exceeding 50- litres locally or in central pharmacies lacking specialised air conditioning and ventilation.
  • Since undiluted ethanol is highly flammable and may ignite at temperatures as low as 10°C, production facilities should directly dilute it to the above mentioned concentration.
  • The flashpoints of ethanol 80% (v/v) and of isopropyl alcohol 75% (v/v) are 17.5°C and 19°C, respectively.
  • National safety guidelines and local legal requirements must be adhered to the storage of ingredients and the final product.

Using 0.5% Chlorine Solution is indicated when instruments can be decontaminated and when to mix a disinfection solution used for cleaning high-risk areas.

Disinfection solution is made with detergent and 0.5% Chlorine Solution.

Chlorine in liquid bleach comes in different concentrations.

Any concentration can be used to make a dilute chlorine solution by applying the following formula:

% Chlorine in liquid bleach
Chlorine desired (0.5%)
-1
=
Total parts of water for each part of bleach

Example: To make a 0.5% chlorine solution from 5% bleach:

5%
0.5%
-1
=
9 parts of water for each part of bleach

Therefore, you must add 1 part of 5% bleach to 9 parts water to make a 0.5% chlorine solution.

Parts can be used for any unit of measure (e.g. litre or gallon) or any container used for measuring, such as a pitcher.

In countries where French products are available, the amount of active chlorine is usually expressed in degrees chlorum.

One degree chlorum is equivalent to 0.3% active chlorine.

questions.question: Who do you protect by following the infection prevention recommendations?
questions.description: By following the infection prevention recommendations you protect the patient and yourself.

questions.question: Infections cannot be prevented, True or False?
questions.description: False, infections can be prevented.

questions.question: What is hand hygiene?
questions.description:
Hand hygiene is defined as:

Using alcohol-based handrub.

Washing hands with soap and running water.

answers.value: Washing hands with soap and running water

questions.question: When should you use alcohol-based handrub?
questions.description:
You should use alcohol-based handrub:

Before and after each procedure.

When hands are visibly clean.

questions.question: Which soap is best to use?
questions.description: The best soap to use is liquid soap from a dispenser

answers.value: Plain soap in a wet container
Plain soap placed in a rack that drains

questions.question: What personal protective equipment at a minimum should you wear while attending a birth?
questions.description: You should, as a minimum wear a clean apron, gloves and closed footwear while attending a birth.

questions.question: If you are running out of gloves, you can use the same pair of gloves for different patients. True or False?
questions.description: False, you should never use the same pair of gloves for different patients.

questions.question: What do you use for cleaning your instruments?
questions.description: You use a soap solution made of water and detergent to clean your instruments.

answers.value: A solution made of water, chlorine and bar soap
A solution made of water, chlorine and detergent
A solution made of water and detergent

questions.question: When are sterile items at risk of becoming contaminated?
questions.description: Sterile items are at risk of becoming contaminated when placed in a sterilized container that is repeatedly opened and closed.

answers.value: When placed in a small, dry sterile container
When placed in a sterilized container that is repeatedly opened and closed

questions.question: Where should sterile items be placed?
questions.description: Sterile items should be placed in a closed cabinet

answers.value: On a shelf so they are easily accessible
Unpacked, at the operational table, ready for use

questions.question: It is not necessary to clean the delivery bed if there was no birth on the bed. True or False?
questions.description: False, it is necessary to clean the delivery bed even if there was no birth on the bed.

questions.question: Which vaccination should all healthcare workers have?
questions.description: All healthcare workers should have a Hepatitis B vaccination.

questions.question: Identify some of the major complications associated with maternal death
questions.description:
Some of the major complications associated with maternal death are:

Hypertensive disorder.

Infections.

Severe bleeding.

questions.question: Identify some of the major complications associated with  neonatal death (0-28 days after birth)
questions.description:
Some of the major complications associated with  neonatal death (0-27 days after birth) are:

Neonatal sepsis.

Prematurity.

questions.question: What is the main cause of infections?
questions.description: The main cause of infections is invisible germs.

questions.question: When healthcare workers transfer germs to patients, how does it primarily occur?
questions.description: Healthcare workers primarily transfer germs to patients through the healthcare workers’ contaminated hands.

questions.question: How is the correct way to perform hand hygiene if your hands are visible clean?
questions.description: Alcohol-based handrub kills most germs.

answers.value: Washing hands with soap and running water

questions.question: Can germs hide under rings, wristwatches and bracelets?
questions.description: Yes, germs can hide under rings, wristwatches and bracelets as it is difficult to clean your jewellery and wristwatch free of germs.

answers.value: No, when hands are washed all germs are gone.
Yes, it is difficult to clean your jewellery and wristwatch free of germs.

questions.question: What should you do if you don’t have paper towels to dry hands with?
questions.description: If you don’t have paper towels to dry hands with, use a clean towel that has not been used before.

answers.value: Use a clean towel that has not been used before

questions.question: Shared towels cannot transfer germs to hands. True or False?
questions.description: False, shared towels can indeed transfer germs to hands.

questions.question: When should you perform hand hygiene?
questions.description:
You should perform hand hygiene:

After contact with patient’s surroundings.

Before a clean procedure.

Before wearing gloves and after removing gloves.

answers.value: Before wearing gloves and after removing gloves

questions.question: In what order should cleaning and storage be arranged?
questions.description:
Cleaning and storage shold be arranged in following order: 

1. Contaminated items 
2. Cleaning
3. Sterilization / High-level disinfection
4. Storage

questions.question: Why is it important to organize the cleaning process?
questions.description: By separating the dirty and clean area contamination are avoided.

answers.value: To avoid contamination by separating the dirty and clean areas
To prevent the healthcare workers from cleaning the instruments

keyLearningPointDetails.description: Spread of HIV and Hep. B

questions.question: How can HIV and Hepatitis B spread?
questions.description: HIV and Hepatitis B only spread through infectious fluids such as blood, genital and amniotic fluids and blood stained fluids.

answers.value: Through all types of body fluids
Through infectious fluids (blood, genital and amniotic fluids and blood stained fluids)

questions.question: When should you choose handrub instead of handwash?
questions.description:
You should choose handrub instead of handwash:

When leaving the clinic.

Before and after each procedure.

questions.question: When should you wash your hands?
questions.description:
You should wash hands:

When hands are visibly dirty.

After touching body fluids.

questions.question: What is the procedure for handwashing?
questions.description:
The procedure for handwashing is:

1. Turn on the water from the tap 
2. Position the hands and wrist downward as you wet them and apply soap
3. Perform 6 steps of rubbing movements
4. Rinse hands with clean running water

answers.value: Turn on the water from the tap
Position the hands and wrist downward as you wet them and apply soap
Rinse hands with clean running water

questions.question: For each procedure, how much alcohol-based handrub do you need?
questions.description: For each procedure, you need one palmful of alcohol-based handrub to clean your hands.

questions.question: If you run out of alcohol-based handrub what do you do?
questions.description:
If you run out of alcohol-based handrub what do you:

Make it yourself.

Ask somebody at the clinic to make it.

Wash your hands instead.

answers.value: Ask somebody at the clinic to make it
I do not perform hand hygiene

questions.question: Labelling on the alcohol-based handrub bottle is important. True or False?
questions.description: True, labelling on the alcohol-based handrub bottle is important.

questions.question: What should you be aware of when removing gloves?
questions.description: When removing gloves you should be aware of not allowing the outside surface to come in contact with the skin.

answers.value: To put them in chlorine solution for reuse
To wash them with soap and water
Not to allow the outside surface to come in contact with the skin

questions.question: Which gloves are recommended while attending a birth?
questions.description: Sterile gloves are preferred while attending a birth.

questions.question: When should you use a disinfection solution?
questions.description: You should use disinfection solution in high-risk areas which consists of table, delivery bed, walls, ceiling, floor and toilet.

answers.value: In a high- and low-risk area

questions.question: When is the transmission of HIV and Hepatitis B most likely?
questions.description: Transmission of HIV and Hepatitis B is most likely by inoculation through the skin.

questions.question: What should you do if you are exposed to HIV or hepatitis B?
questions.description: If you are exposed to HIV or hepatitis B you should take post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP).

questions.question: Should soap be placed in a wet container?
questions.description: No, soap should not be placed in a wet container, because germs will grow.

answers.value: Yes, because when the soap is already wet, you save water

questions.question: Why is it not recommended to air-dry hands after hand wash?
questions.description: It is recommended to use paper towel after hand wash if available

questions.question: How do you mix alcohol-based handrub?
questions.description: You mix alcohol-based handrub by following the Safe Delivery App formula.

answers.value: Follow the Safe Delivery App formula

chapters.content:
Septic Abortion

Septic abortion is diagnosed by the following signs:

Tender uterus

AND

Abnormal, foul smelling vaginal discharge

OR

Rebound tenderness

OR

Any signs of shock (systolic blood pressure below 90) or pre-shock (pulse above 90).

OR

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for.

At signs of septic abortion or at excessive vaginal bleeding:

Evacuation of the uterus must be performed with no delay!Do not delay by awaiting “antibiotic coverage”!
CALL FOR HELP!

Airway

Position so airway is not occluded or at risk of aspiration.

Breathing

If gasping or absent ventilate with bag and mask.

Circulation

Insert 2 wide bore IV cannulas.

Give at least 2L fluids IV, normal saline or Ringer’s lactate fast.

Insert indwelling urine catheter to monitor in- and output.

Drugs

Give antibiotics intravenous according to local guidelines, for example:

Ampicillin 1 g/6 hrs.

AND

Gentamicin 80 mg/12 hrs.

AND

Metronidazole 500 mg/8 hrs.

This must not delay the lifesaving EVACUATION of the uterus.Give antibiotics while you start the procedure.If antibiotics are not available, perform evacuation and give antibiotics afterwards.

Evacuate Uterus

Give appropriate analgesia then evacuate using no-touch technique.

Until 12-14 weeks of gestation Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA) is the preferred method.

At a higher gestational age evacuation is by Dilatation and Curettage (D&C) and should be performed in a referral facility.

PERIPHERAL LEVEL

If at a peripheral level without possibility of performing manual vacuum aspiration: Give Antibiotics intra musculary and refer IMMEDIATELY

1. Monitor vital signs and urine output closely until stable.
  2. Treat with IV antibiotics until 48 hours after the woman is fever free, then oral antibiotics for 5-7 days.
  3. Before discharge, advise on family planning and check for sexually transmitted diseases and HIV/AIDS.

Do not refer if emergency is not controlled!

Never refer a patient with uncontrolled bleeding, retained placenta, uncontrolled hypertension, unevacuated septic or haemorrhagic abortion or septic shock.

Remove placenta by trained provider.

In cases of prolonged labour:
- If at a peripheral facility, refer the woman to a higher centre with her partograph for further management.

- At a referral facility, amniotomy may be done (also for HIV+ women if on antiretroviral therapy). Reassess in 2 hours and decide on further management if there is insufficient progress.

After emergency management and when in a stable condition, discuss decision of referral with woman and relatives.

Quickly organise transport and possible financial aid.

Inform the referral center.

Accompany the woman.

It is crucial that she is accompanied by a health worker who is trained in delivery care and able to manage an emergency situation, if it recurrs during transport.

Consider to bring a relative who can donate blood.

Bring

Referral note.

Essential emergency drugs:

  • Oxytocin and Ergometrine (alternatively Misoprostol) for treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
  • Oxytocin for IM injection immediately postpartum
  • Hydralazine for IV treatment of elevated blood pressure
  • Magnesium Sulphate for eclampsia
  • Calcium Gluconate for intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate
  • Ampicillin for infections
  • Diazepam for pain relief

Supplies:

  • Delivery set
  • Towels
  • IV-equipment + IV fluids
  • Foetoscope or Doppler
  • Blood pressure monitor
  • Ambu bag
  • Suction bulb

During Transport

Observe vital signs and level of consciousness.

If pregnant check FHR.

In case of excessive vaginal bleeding apply bimanual compression.

If the bleeding does not stop apply aorta compression (can be maintained up to 6 hours).

If the woman’s condition permits:

Keep record of all IV fluids, medications given, time of administration and the woman´s condition.

If in labour during transport:

FHR every half an hour.

If pushing and superficial breathing is not enough to repress this urge, stop the transport and deliver the woman.

drugDetails.content:
Indications and Usage

Ampicillin is a B-lactamantibiotics effective on gram positive as well as negative bacterial infections.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

1 g intravenously every 6 hours (at sepsis initially each 4 hours).

Children:

First week of life:

50 mg/kg per dose every 12 hours intravenously or intramuscularly.

Week 2-4 of life:

50 mg/kg per dose every 8 hours intravenously or intramuscularly.

Contraindications

Allergy to penicillin.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are diarrhea and skin rash.

Uncommon reactions are nausea, vomiting, stomatitis, glossitis, pseudomembraneous colitis, lowered platelets, anemia and urticaria.

Anaphylactic shock is rare.

Indications and Usage

Diazepam is a benzodiazepine.

Diazepam is used to treat anxiety, agitation and convulsions.

Can also be used as analgesia before a painful procedure.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

Before procedure:

10 mg IV OR

10-20 mg IM OR

20 mg rectally OR

Second dose:

10 mg IV/IM/rectally

Children:

For convulsions:

give 0.5 mg/kg rectally once.

If convulsions persist after 10 minutes repeat 0.5mg/kg rectally one more time.

If convulsions persists after additional 10 min give 0.4 mg/kg intravenously maximum once.

If convulsions occur in early pregnancy or if Magnesium Sulphate toxicity occurs or Magnesium Sulphate is not available.

Loading dose IV:

Give Diazepam 10 mg IV slowly over 2 minutes.

If convulsions recur, repeat 10 mg.

Maintenace dose:

Give Diazepam 40 mg in 500 ml IV fluids (normal saline or Ringer’s lactate) titrated over 6-8 hours to keep the woman sedated but rousable.

Stop the maintenance dose if breathing is affected.

Assist ventilation if necessary with mask and bag.

Do not give more than 100 mg in 24 hours.

If IV access is not possible (e.g. during convulsion), give Diazepam rectally.

Loading dose rectally:

Give 20 mg (4 ml) in a 10 ml syringe (or urinary catheter):

Remove the needle, lubricate the barrel and insert the syringe into the rectum to half its length.

Discharge the contents and leave the syringe in place, holding the buttocks together for 10 minutes to prevent expulsion of the drug.

If convulsions recur, repeat 10 mg.

Maintenance dose:

Give additional 10 mg (2 ml) every hour during transport.

Contraindications

Alcohol intoxication.

Severe respiratory or liver illness.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are drowsiness and confusion.

Uncommon reactions are muscle weakness, coordination difficulties, headache, concentration difficulty and dizziness.

Rare reactions are respiratory depression or respiratory stop, aggression, hallucinations, psychosis, and allergic reactions.

Diazepam should not be used long term as tolerance and addiction occurs commonly.

Indications and Usage

Aminoglycoside antibiotic indicated for treatment of severe or serious bacterial infections in adults and children.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

240 mg intravenously once a day.

Children (First week of life):

2.5 mg per kg every 12 hours if term; 1.5 mg per kg every 12 hours if preterm intravenously or intramuscularly.

Treat for at least two days.

Children (Weeks 2-4 of life):

7.5 mg/kg per dose once a day intravenously or intramuscularly.

Contraindications

Allergy to aminoglycosides.

Treatment should not be more than 3 days if the patient is suffering from renal failure (oliguria or elevated creatinine).

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are kidney affection, hearing loss, and tinnitus.

Uncommon reactions are liver affection, increased or lowered blood pressure, respiratory depression, lowered platelets, joint and muscle pain, depression, coordination disturbances, skin rash, itching, visual disturbances, urticaria and anaphylactic reactions.

Rare reactions are deafness, hair loss, low urine production and necrosis of the skin.

Indications and Usage

Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID).

It works by reducing hormones that cause inflammation and pain in the body.

Ibuprofen is used to reduce fever and treat pain or inflammation caused by many conditions such as headache, toothache, back pain, arthritis, menstrual cramps, or minor injury.

Dosage and Administration

For pain relief give 400-600 mg. Ibuprofen orally.

The maximum amount of Ibuprofen for adults is 800 milligrams per dose or 3,200 mg per day (4 maximum doses).

Use only the smallest amount needed to get relief from your pain, swelling, or fever.

Contraindications

Ibuprofen is contraindicated for use in patients with:

Known hypersensitivity or idiosyncratic reaction to Ibuprofen (or any of the other ingredients in the product) known hypersensitivity to aspirin and other NSAIDs.

Asthma that is aspirin or NSAID sensitive.

Active gastrointestinal bleeding or peptic ulceration.

Adverse Reactions

Adverse effects include nausea, dyspepsia, diarrhoea, constipation, gastrointestinal ulceration/bleeding, headache, dizziness, rash, salt and fluid retention, and hypertension.

Infrequent adverse effects include esophageal ulceration, heart failure, hyperkalemia, renal impairment, confusion, and bronchospasm. Ibuprofen can exacerbate asthma, sometimes fatally.

Indications and Usage

Metronidazole is a 5-nitroimidazole antibiotic used on obligate anaerobe bacterias and protozoes.

Treatment of anaerobic bacterial infections and trichomona vaginalis, intestinal amoebae and giardiasis.

Dosage and administration

500 mg. every 12 hours for 7 days or until 48 hours after the patient is fever free.

Contraindications

Allergy to Metronidazole.

It is very important to note, that alcohol must not be taken together with or three days following treatment with metronidazole as it can cause a severe adverse reaction.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are a taste of metal sensation, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and transient liver affection.

Uncommon reactions are joint- and muscle pain, headache and visual disturbances.

Rare reactions are pancreatitis, lowered platelets, dizziness, sensitivity disturbances, confusion and skin rash.

Anaphylactic shock is very rare.

Indications and usage

Strong opioid analgetic drug.

Dosage and administration

5-10 mg intramuscularly.

2.5-5 mg intravenously.

Can be repeated if insufficient response after 30 minutes up to a maximum dose of 60 mg over 24 hours.

Contraindications

History of severe reactions to opioids (respiratory stop).

Severe respiratory insufficiency, paralytic ileus, liver insufficiency.

Should not be given in first trimester.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are nausea, vomiting, euphoria, drowsiness, dizziness, fainting and mood disturbances.

Uncommon reactions are agitation, trembling, confusion, fits, urticaria, respiratory depression, increased or decreased pulse and constipation.

Rare reactions are hallucinations, itching, skin rash and anaphylactic reactions.

chapters.content:
Manual vacuum aspiration, or MVA, is a technique for uterine evacuation whose low cost, simplicity and portability make it an especially valuable reproductive-health technology.

MVA is used for evacuation of the uterus at incomplete first trimester abortions up to a gestational age of 12 weeks.

Especially at septic abortion and strong bleeding in relation to abortion the procedure is a life saving emergency procedure that must be performed with no delay.

Antibiotics should not delay the procedure.

Ideally antibiotics are given at the start of the procedure, though the procedure can be performed without antibiotics.

Cleaning After Use

Step 1:

Soak instruments immediately after use

Following the procedure, decontaminate and clean all aspirators that will be reused, by first putting unlock and open jointed instruments in a 0.5 % chlorine solution for maximum 10 min.

Hereafter clean the aspirators with a brush in a soap solution. Be aware the soap solution is made of detergent and water, not hand soap.

Rinse items with clean running water to remove all detergent.

Step 2:

Clean all aspirators thoroughly in warm water and detergent, not soap.

Wear gloves and face protection.

Disassemble the aspirator by pulling the cylinder out of the valve.

Remove the cap by pressing down the cap-release tabs with one hand and pulling off the cap with the other hand.

Open the hinged valve by pulling open the clasp.

Place right thumb alongside the right valve button and left thumb on the valve latch.

With the left thumb, pull up and to the left on the valve latch while pushing down and out on the valve body with the right thumb.

Remove the valve liner.

Disengage the collar stop by sliding it sideways under the retaining clip, or remove the collar stop completely.

Pull the plunger completely out.

Displace the plunger O-ring by squeezing its sides and rolling it into the groove below.

Emptying the bladder with a urine catheter is indicated:

  1. If a woman in labour fails to urinate spontaneously and the progress of labour is dissatisfactory, OR
  2. In cases of post partum haemorrhage, AND
  3. In any severely ill patient with for example sepsis or severe preeclampsia to monitor the urine output. In this case, the catheter should stay in place until the condition improves.

The urine should be clear, if not, there is a urine tract infection and antibiotics should be administered.

All patients in a critical state (sepsis, severe preeclampsia, eclampsia, bleeding, shock) must have a permanent catheter, and the hourly urine output should be at least 30 millilitres.

If less, the underlying cause should be treated and fluid replacement considered, although not more than one litre over 8 hours for preeclampsia as the risk of fluid overload and pulmonary oedema is increased.

Before applying a permanent catheter, the area around the urethra should be cleaned twice with gauze swabs and normal saline water.

Intravenous access is used to administer fluids and drugs.

Equipment for intravenous/intramuscular access should be located in the delivery room.

It should be available at all health facilities for adults as well as children.

It includes:

Antiseptic solution to clean the surrounding skin, syringes, intravenous cannulas, venflons, a stasis hose/band, tapes and cannulas.

Adults:

The grey and green cannulas have a large diameter.

Using them makes the fluid enter the body more rapidly.

Children:

For insertion of an intravenous cannula in the neonate select a suitable vein to place the cannula or a gauge 21 or 23 butterfly needle.

Peripheral vein:

  • Identify an accessible peripheral vein, see illustration.
  • An assistant should keep the position of the limb steady and should act as a tourniquet by obstructing the venous return with his or her fingers lightly closed around the limb. Alternatively use a stasis hose/band.
  • Clean the surrounding skin with an antiseptic solution (such as spirit, iodine, isopropyl alcohol or 7+ % alcohol solution), then introduce the cannula into the vein and insert most of its length. Fix the catheter securely with tape. Apply a splint with the limb in an appropriate position (e.g. elbow extended, wrist slightly flexed).

Scalp Vein:

These are often used in children ages less than 2 years but are most suitable in young infants.

  • Find a suitable scalp vein (usually in the midline of the forehead, the temporal area or above or behind the ear).
  • Shave the area if necessary, and clean the skin with an antiseptic solution. The assistant should occlude the vein proximal to the site of puncture. Fill a syringe and leave the end of the tubing open. Introduce the butterfly needle as described above. Blood flowing back slowly through the tubing indicates that the needle is in the vein.
  • Care should be taken not to cannulate an artery, which is recognised by palpation. If there is a pulsatile spurting of blood, withdraw the needle and apply pressure until the bleeding stops; then look for the vein.

questions.question: Globally, how many women undergo an unsafe abortion each year?
questions.description: Globally 20 million (2 crore) women undergo an unsafe abortion.

questions.question: What is the most common life-threatening complication to abortion?
questions.description: The most common life-threatening complication to abortion is septic abortion.

Any woman of reproductive age with fever
Only when a woman herself admits to have had an illegal abortion
Any woman of reproductive age with vaginal bleeding

For all needing medical treatment – drugs might harm the foetus

For all woman presenting with lower abdominal pain, fever or vaginal bleeding

For all women that did not have their menstrual periods when expected
For all needing medical treatment – drugs might harm the foetus

questions.question: What is true regarding septic abortion?

True about septic abortion is:

The septic abortion is like an abscess in the uterus and antibiotics will often not help much.

Evacuation of the uterus is the correct effective management.

Evacuation of the uterus is the correct effective management

answers.value: Yes, always! And with no delay! The septic abortion is like an abscess in the uterus
Only sometimes – if antibiotics have not had an effect within 24-48 hours

After 24-48 hours of antibiotic treatment with no effect
Never perform evacuation of the uterus at a septic abortion

Antibiotic coverage should not be awaited.

Antibiotics work best when given at the beginning of the procedure
Evacuation should not be performed at septic abortion

questions.question: How urgent is the management of a women diagnosed with septic abortion or excessive vaginal bleeding?
questions.description:
If a women is diagnosed with septic abortion or excessive vaginal bleeding management is:

Very urgent! You must act now! The uterus must be evacuated!

Urgent, Initial management with antibiotics should be started within 2-4 hours
It is not a life-or-death situation. Others might need help first
Not really urgent. They brought themselves into this situation

questions.question: At septic abortion, what is the correct order of actions?
questions.description:
At septic abortion, the correct order of actions is:

Call for help, assess airway and ensure breathing

Establish intravenous access and give fluid resuscitation 2 liters of Normal saline or Ringer’s lactate FAST

Evacuate the uterus IMMEDIATELY!

Give broad-spectrum antibiotics

If no possibility of performing evacuation of the uterus; give antibiotics and refer IMMEDIATELY.

Start with the thinnest and proceed to the thickest.

Insert with a quick movement until you cannot go any further

After the MVA you should:

chapters.content:
Severe Preeclampsia is one of the following:

  1. Severely elevated blood pressure (160 mmHg or higher systolic OR 110 mmHg or higher diastolic), OR
  2. Persistent severe headache OR
  3. Visual disturbances like flashing lights or blurry vision, OR
  4. Persistent upper abdominal pain, OR
  5. Respiratory distress that could be caused by pulmonary oedema, OR
  6. Decreased urine production (less than 25 ml per hour)

Eclampsia is when a pregnant woman develops generalised seizures.

Usually these women suffer from preeclampsia though 10-20% of women with eclampsia have a normal blood pressure.

Consider as differential diagnosis cerebral malaria or meningitis where fever will be present.

If no signs of severe preeclampsia (see definitions):

Send home.

Schedule follow up appointment in 3-4 days, instruct in danger signs.

Plan delivery at referral facility, induction of labour at gestational age of 38-39 weeks if this procedure is performed and if gestational age is known.

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for.

Admit and observe.

Assess BP every 8 hours.

If high blood pressure persists start oral antihypertensives for example:

Labetatol starting dose: 100 mg orally every 12 hours

OR

Methyldopa starting dose: 250 mg orally every 8 hours.

See drug list for more details.

If blood pressure is reduced to between 140-150 systolic and 90-100 diastolic AND if there are no signs of severe preeclampsia (see definitions), the patient can be sent home.

Schedule follow up appointment in 3-4 days, instruct in danger signs.

Plan for delivery at referral facility, induction of labour at gestational age 38-39 if this procedure is performed and if gestational age is known.

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for.

See definitions.

Admit and treat.

The single most important aim is to keep systolic BP below 160 mmHg!

Insert indwelling urine catheter.

Monitor each ½ hour until stable, then each 8 hours:

  1. Fluid balance
  2. Respiratory rate
  3. Blood pressure
  4. Tendon reflexes
  5. Foetal heart rate

If severe features persist: Plan referral for delivery within 24 hours.

Managing Blood Pressure

At blood pressure between 150-160/100-110 start oral antihypertensives for example:

Labetatol starting dose: 100 mg orally every 12 hours.

OR

Methyldopa starting dose: 250 mg orally every 8 hours.

Persisting blood pressure =/> 160 syst. or =/> 110 diastolic must be treated IV.

See drug list for more details.

Assess blood pressure every 15 minutes.

Repeat after 30 minutes until BP is below 160/110.

See drug list for more details.

Prevention of Eclampsia

If at a peripheral facility give pre-referral dose: 50% MgSO4 – 5 grams in each buttock deep IM and refer the patient.

At all other facilities, treat the patient the following way: Give magnesium sulphate. As a loading dose you give 4 grams of 50% MgSO4 diluted in 12 ml normal saline or distilled water to make 20% MgSO4 solution and then give slow IV over 20 minutes.

If normal tendon reflexes and breathing: Proceed directly to giving maintenance dose Magnesium Sulphate 5 gm 50% solution deep IM in 1 buttock, and after 4 hours in the other (You can add 1 ml. 2% lidocaine for pain relief).

See drug list for more details.

Never give Magnesium Sulphate intravenously fast, as this causes cardiac arrest!

Beware of toxicity!

The first sign is loss of tendon reflexes; a more severe sign is respiratory depression with a respiratory rate < 12 per minute.

Then you don’t give the intramuscular dose of Magnesium Sulphate. Instead you give the antidote Calcium Gluconate 1 gr. IV over three minutes.

At heart arrest you give the antidote IV push.

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for.Call for help!
  1. Check Airway and Breathing.
  2. Fits are self-limiting; while convulsing, prevent the woman from trauma and turn her on the left side.
  3. Insert IV lines.
  4. If at a peripheral facility give pre-referral dose: 50% MgSO4 – 5 grams in each buttock deep IM and refer the patient.
  5. At all other facilities, treat the patient the following way: Give magnesium sulphate. As a loading dose you give 4 grams of 50% MgSO4 diluted in 12 ml normal saline or distilled water to make 20% MgSO4 solution and then give slow IV over 20 minutes.
Never give Magnesium Sulphate intravenously fast, as this causes heart arrest!

If no signs of toxicity, proceed directly to giving the first maintenance dose of Magnesium Sulphate; 2 doses of 5 gm deep IM (50% solution) one in each buttock, and after 4 hours in the other (You can add ½ ml. 2% lidocaine for pain relief).

See drug list for more details.

Beware of toxicity

The first sign is loss of tendon reflexes. Also pay attention to urine output, since intoxication is seen in patients with an output < 25-30 ml/hour.A more severe sign is respiratory depression with a respiratory rate of < 12per minute. Then you don’t give the intramuscular dose of Magnesium Sulphate.

At a respiratory rate of < 12 per minute you give the antidote Calcium Gluconate 1g IVover three minutes. At heart arrest give the antidote IV push.

Do not refer if emergency is not controlled!

Never refer a patient with uncontrolled bleeding, retained placenta, uncontrolled hypertension, unevacuated septic or haemorrhagic abortion or septic shock.

Remove placenta by trained provider.

In cases of prolonged labour:
- If at a peripheral facility, refer the woman to a higher centre with her partograph for further management.

- At a referral facility, amniotomy may be done (also for HIV+ women if on antiretroviral therapy). Reassess in 2 hours and decide on further management if there is insufficient progress.

After emergency management and when in a stable condition, discuss decision of referral with woman and relatives.

Quickly organise transport and possible financial aid.

Inform the referral center.

Accompany the woman.

It is crucial that she is accompanied by a health worker who is trained in delivery care and able to manage an emergency situation, if it recurrs during transport.

Consider to bring a relative who can donate blood.

Bring

Referral note.

Essential emergency drugs:

  • Oxytocin and Ergometrine (alternatively Misoprostol) for treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
  • Oxytocin for IM injection immediately postpartum
  • Hydralazine for IV treatment of elevated blood pressure
  • Magnesium Sulphate for eclampsia
  • Calcium Gluconate for intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate
  • Ampicillin for infections
  • Diazepam for pain relief

Supplies:

  • Delivery set
  • Towels
  • IV-equipment + IV fluids
  • Foetoscope or Doppler
  • Blood pressure monitor
  • Ambu bag
  • Suction bulb

During Transport

Observe vital signs and level of consciousness.

If pregnant check FHR.

In case of excessive vaginal bleeding apply bimanual compression.

If the bleeding does not stop apply aorta compression (can be maintained up to 6 hours).

If the woman’s condition permits:

Keep record of all IV fluids, medications given, time of administration and the woman´s condition.

If in labour during transport:

FHR every half an hour.

If pushing and superficial breathing is not enough to repress this urge, stop the transport and deliver the woman.

drugDetails.content:
Indications and Usage

In case of intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate where withdrawing the Magnesium supplementation is not sufficient:

give the antidote Calcium Gluconate IV.

The actions of magnesium in neuromuscular and cardiac function are antagonized by calcium.

Dosage and Administration

At Magnesium Sulphate intoxication with loss of tendon reflexes and a respiratory rate < 12/min. give Calcium Gluconate 1 g (10 mL of 10% solution) IV slowly over three minutes, until respiration begins to counteract the effect of magnesium sulfate.

At heart arrest give Calcium Gluconate 1 g (10 ml. of 10% solution) IV push.

This dose may be repeated once if necessary in severe cases of hypermagnesemia (where discontinuation of exogenous magnesium is inadequate) to temporarily reverse many of the toxic effects of magnesium in the central nervous system.

Contraindications

Calcium salts are contraindicated in patients with ventricular fibrillation or hypercalcemia.

Intravenous administration of calcium is contraindicated when serum calcium levels are above normal.

Adverse Reactions

Nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, constipation, dry mouth, increased thirst, increased urination, tingling sensations, hot flashes, and a chalky taste following intravenous administration.

Indications and Usage

Antihypertensive drug used for example at preeclampsia and pregnancy induced hypertension.

During pregnancy systolic blood pressure above 160 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure above 110 mm Hg on repeated readings should be treated and delivery planned within 24 hours.

CAUTION: Diastolic blood pressure should not be lowered below 90 mm Hg to avoid effect on foetal circulation.

Dosage and Administration

5 mg IV slowly (3-4 minutes) every 30 minutes until blood pressure is reduced to below 160 mmHg systolic and 110 mmHg diastolic.

It is important that before delivery the diastolic blood pressure should not be lowered below 90 mmHg, otherwise the blood supply to the fetus might be compromised.

Contraindications

Tachycardia, lupus erythematosus disseminatus, and rheumatoid arthritis.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are headache, flushing, tachycardia, allergic reactions and abdominal pain.

Uncommon adverse reactions are nose congestion, feeling disorders, increased tear flow, and tremor.

Indications and Usage

An adrenergic a- and b- receptor antagonist used to treat hypertension in pregnancy.

A persistent blood pressure at or above 150 mm Hg systolic or at or above 100 mm Hg diastolic should be treated.

CAUTION:

Diastolic blood pressure should not be lowered below 80 mm Hg to avoid affecting foetal circulation.

Dosage and Administration

Non-severe hypertension

Systolic BP: >/= 150 mmHg or diastolic BP >/= 100 mmHg.

Administer 200 mg orally every six to 12 hours.

The maximum dose is 1,200 mg per 24 hours.

Severe hypertension

Systolic BP: >/= 160 mmHg or diastolic BP >/= 110 mmHg.

Oral treatment:

Administer 200 mg.

Repeat dose after one hour until the treatment goal is achieved (an important principle is to maintain blood pressures above the lower limits of normal).

The maximum dose is 1200 mg in 24 hours.

Intravenous treatment:

Administer 10 mg IV.

If response is inadequate after 10 minutes, administer 20 mg IV.

The dose can be doubled to 40 mg and then 80 mg with 10 minute intervals between each increased dose until blood pressure is lowered below threshold.

The maximum total dose is 300 mg; then switch to oral treatment.

Once blood pressure is reduced to non-severe levels (lower than 160/110 mmHg), ongoing treatment should be continued using oral medication.

In case of severe preeclampsia:

Delivery within 24 hours (48 hours if condition is stable and there is a need for awaiting lung matuaration of the foetus).

Contraindications

Women with congestive heart failure, hypovolaemic shock or predisposition to bronchospasm (asthma) should not receive Labetalol.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are nausea, lethargy, orthostatic hypotension, dyspnoea, dizziness, headache, prickling sensation in the scalp, skin rash and itching, and blurry vision.

Uncommon adverse reactions are vomiting, abdominal pain, bronchial constriction, and shivering.

Rare adverse reactions are bradycardia.

Indications and Usage

To treat eclamptic fits and to prevent eclamptic fits (should be given to all women with severe pre-eclampsia during delivery).

Magnesium Sulphate is the drug of choice for the treatment of women with eclampsia.

The duration of treatment should normally not exceed 24 hours beyond delivery or the last convulsion, whichever occurs last.

Dosage and Administration

Always have the antidote Calcium Gluconate ready, when you start treatment with Magnesium Sulphate.

Magnesium Sulphate Loading dose (IV)

Give 4 g of 20% Magnesium Sulphate solution IV over 20 minutes (if 20% is not available see below).

Follow promptly with the first maintenance dose (IM).

10 g of 50% Magnesium Sulphate solution:

Give 5 g in each buttock as a deep IM injection with 1 mL of 2% lidocaine in the same syringe.

Ensure aseptic technique when giving Magnesium Sulphate deep IM injection.

After four hours:

Maintenance dose continued (IM):

Give 5 g of 50% Magnesium Sulphate solution with 1 mL of 2% Lidocaine in the same syringe by deep IM injection into alternate buttocks.

Repeat every four hours.

Change side with each injection.

Continue treatment for 24 hours after birth or the last convulsion, whichever occurs last.

If fits occur after Magnesium Sulphate has been started give a reduced loading dose of 2 grams intravenously over 10 minutes.

How to mix a 20% solution

To prepare a 20% Magnesium Sulphate solution from a 50% concentrated solution. Do the following: Take the number of mL of the required equivalent gram in the 50% concentrated solution and multiply it with 1.5. This gives you the mL of normal saline or distilled water that needs to be added to the 50% concentrated solution.

Ex. In a 5g/10mL 50% solution, take 8 mL (4g). To get a 20 % solution: 8 X 1.5 = 12 mL.

12 mL of normal saline or glucose has to be add to the 8 mL solution, in total 20 mL.

Contraindications

Renal failure and atrioventricular block.

Uliguria is not a contraindication for Magnesium Sulphate treatment, but pay attention particularly to women with reduced urine output:

If signs of respiratory depression (respiratory rate below 15 per minute) the maintenance dose should also be postponed.

Adverse Reactions

Magnesium Sulphate can be toxic, the first signs of overdose is the absence of tendon reflexes, so before giving maintenance dose each 4 hours, tendon reflexes must be checked, if absent, the injection should not be given and tendon reflexes checked after another 4 hours.

At a respiratory rate less than 12/min. the antidote Calcium Gluconate 1 gram should be given intravenously over 3 minutes.

At cardiac arrest the antidote must be given push.

Magnesium Sulphate should not be combined with Diazepam or any other anticonvulsant as the risk of severe adverse reactions is considerably increased.

The so-called “lytic cocktail” combining different drugs is life-threatening and should never be given.

A common and not serious adverse reaction is flushing.

Indications and Usage

Hypertension, persistant blood pressure of 150 mm Hg systolic or above or diastolic of 100 mm Hg or above.

Dosage and Administration

Non-severe hypertension; systolic BP >/= 150 mmHg or diastolic BP >/= 100 mmHg:

250 mg orally every 6-8 hours.

Can be gradually increased up to 500 mg every 6 hours.

Maximum dose: 2000 mg per 24 hours.

For fast control of the blood pressure this is not the drug to choose as it works rather slow.

Give Methyldopa and at the same time give a quick-acting drug like Labetalol or Hydralazine.

In case of severe preeclampsia:

(48 hours if condition is stable and there is a need for awaiting lung matuaration of a foetus (GA: 24-34)).

Contraindications

Active hepatic disease, such as acute hepatitis and active cirrhosis.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are; swelling of feet or lower legs, drowsiness, dryness of mouth, and headache.

Uncommon adverse reactions are; mental depression or anxiety, nightmares or unusually vivid dreams, numbness, tingling, pain, or weakness in hands or feet, slow heartbeat, and stuffy nose.

Rare adverse reactions are; dark or amber urine, diarrhoea or stomach cramps (severe or continuous), fever, chills, troubled breathing, and fast heartbeat, general feeling of discomfort or illness or weakness, joint pain, pale stools, skin rash or itching, yellow eyes or skin.

Indications and Usage

Calcium antagonist used to treat hypertension in pregnancy.

CAUTION: Diastolic blood pressure should not be lowered below 90 mmHg.

It is not uncommon that Nifedipine actually lowers the blood pressure below this point, and therefore should not be given as the drug of first choice.

(Alternatives could be Labetalol or Methyldopa for oral treatment and Hydralazine for IV treatment).

In case of severe preeclampsia delivery should be planned within 24 hours (48 hours if the woman's condition leaves time for lungmaturation of a fetus between GA 24 and 34).

Tocolysis:

Nifedipine can stop contractions at threatening preterm birth before 34 weeks of gestation to give time for lung maturation therapy (Dexamethasone or Betamethasone).

Tocolysis must not be given if chorioamnionitis is suspected.

Dosage and Administration

See CAUTION under "indications and usage".

In some settings, nifedipine is available in more than one formulation (e.g. immediate-release, intermediate-release and sustained-release).

Immediate-release nifedipine is included here, unless we indicate otherwise.

To avoid medication errors, it is important to specify and confirm the nifedipine formulation before administering it.

Non-severe hypertension- Systolic BP: >/= 150 mmHg or diastolic BP: >/= 100 mmHg.

Administer 10–20 mg orally every 12 hours.

The maximum dose is 120 mg per 24 hours.

Severe hypertension- Systolic BP: >/= 160 mmHg or diastolic BP >/= 110 mmHg:

Oral treatment:

Administer 10 mg orally.

Repeat dose after 30 minutes if response is inadequate until optimal blood pressure is reached.

The maximum total dose is 30 mg in the acute treatment setting - Other treatment options should be considered if blood pressure is not lowered within the acute treatment phase of 90 minutes with 30 mg immediate-release.

The antihypertensive effect is fastest if given sublingually but the effect can be to strong and cause hypotension and compromised fetal circulation.

Tocolysis:

10 mg orally every 15 min until contractions stop for a maximum of four doses, then 20 mg oral every 6 hours.

Treatment should not exceed 24 hours.

Tocolysis is contraindicated if chorioamnionitis or abrupted placenta is suspected. Give a tocolytic drug (e.g. nifedipine) to provide a window for administration of antenatal corticosteroids and/or in-utero fetal transfer to an appropriate neonatal health care setting: Give a loading dose of 20 mg nifedipine immediate-release sublingually.

If required, give an additional 10 mg every 15 minutes up to a maximum of 40 mg in the first hour.

Follow up with 20 mg sustained-release tablet (pay attention to the formulation) orally daily for up to 48 hours or until transfer is completed, whichever comes first.

Monitor maternal and fetal condition (pulse, blood pressure, signs of respiratory distress, uterine contractions, loss of amniotic fluid or blood, fetal heart rate, fluid balance).

Note: Do not give tocolytic drugs for more than 48 hours.

  • Do not give a combination of tocolytic agents as there is no additional benefit.
  • Tocolytics should not be used in the following conditions: - preterm prelabour rupture of membranes (PPROM) - chorioamnionitis - placental abruption - cardiac disease.

Contraindications

Treatment with Rifampicin. Suspected fetal distress, suspected abruption of placenta, suspected chorioamnionitis. Tocolytics should not be used in the following conditions: - preterm prelabour rupture of membranes (PPROM) - chorioamnionitis - placental abruption - cardiac disease. CAUTION: see above, should not be the first drug of choice to treat hypertension.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are constipation, vasodilatation, edema, headache, flushing, dizzyness, tiredness, and itching.

Uncommon adverse reactions are nausea, dryness of the mouth, heart palpitations, respiratory distress, nose bleeding, joint pain, anxiety, sleeping disturbances, frequent urge for and painful urination, visual disturbances and allergic reactions.

Rare adverse reactions are urticaria and other severe allergic reactions.

chapters.content:
Emptying the bladder with a urine catheter is indicated:

  1. If a woman in labour fails to urinate spontaneously and the progress of labour is dissatisfactory, OR
  2. In cases of post partum haemorrhage, AND
  3. In any severely ill patient with for example sepsis or severe preeclampsia to monitor the urine output. In this case, the catheter should stay in place until the condition improves.

The urine should be clear, if not, there is a urine tract infection and antibiotics should be administered.

All patients in a critical state (sepsis, severe preeclampsia, eclampsia, bleeding, shock) must have a permanent catheter, and the hourly urine output should be at least 30 millilitres.

If less, the underlying cause should be treated and fluid replacement considered, although not more than one litre over 8 hours for preeclampsia as the risk of fluid overload and pulmonary oedema is increased.

Before applying a permanent catheter, the area around the urethra should be cleaned twice with gauze swabs and normal saline water.

Intravenous access is used to administer fluids and drugs.

Equipment for intravenous/intramuscular access should be located in the delivery room.

It should be available at all health facilities for adults as well as children.

It includes:

Antiseptic solution to clean the surrounding skin, syringes, intravenous cannulas, venflons, a stasis hose/band, tapes and cannulas.

Adults:

The grey and green cannulas have a large diameter.

Using them makes the fluid enter the body more rapidly.

Children:

For insertion of an intravenous cannula in the neonate select a suitable vein to place the cannula or a gauge 21 or 23 butterfly needle.

Peripheral vein:

  • Identify an accessible peripheral vein, see illustration.
  • An assistant should keep the position of the limb steady and should act as a tourniquet by obstructing the venous return with his or her fingers lightly closed around the limb. Alternatively use a stasis hose/band.
  • Clean the surrounding skin with an antiseptic solution (such as spirit, iodine, isopropyl alcohol or 7+ % alcohol solution), then introduce the cannula into the vein and insert most of its length. Fix the catheter securely with tape. Apply a splint with the limb in an appropriate position (e.g. elbow extended, wrist slightly flexed).

Scalp Vein:

These are often used in children ages less than 2 years but are most suitable in young infants.

  • Find a suitable scalp vein (usually in the midline of the forehead, the temporal area or above or behind the ear).
  • Shave the area if necessary, and clean the skin with an antiseptic solution. The assistant should occlude the vein proximal to the site of puncture. Fill a syringe and leave the end of the tubing open. Introduce the butterfly needle as described above. Blood flowing back slowly through the tubing indicates that the needle is in the vein.
  • Care should be taken not to cannulate an artery, which is recognised by palpation. If there is a pulsatile spurting of blood, withdraw the needle and apply pressure until the bleeding stops; then look for the vein.

< 25 ml/hour.

Important causes to consider in a pregnant woman with generalized seizures are:

Eclampsia.

Cerebral malaria.

Meningitis.

questions.question: Preeclampsia is caused by?
questions.description: Pre-eclampsia is caused by pregnancy.

questions.question: It is only necessary to measure BP if there is protein in the urine. True or false?
questions.description: False, it is not only necessary to measure BP if there is protein in the urine.

answers.value: Measure the BP after 1 hour of rest in a reclined position
Refer immediately to higher level facility

questions.question: If first BP is above 160 systolic, what will you do next?
questions.description: If first BP is above 160 diastolic, you measure the BP again after only 10 minutes.

Measure the BP again after only 10 minutes

questions.description:
If a pregnant woman has a confirmed elevated BP, you do the following:

Perform a urine dipstick to check for protein.

Ask about headache, visual disturbances, dizziness, nausea and upper abdominal pain.

answers.value: Perform a urine dipstick to check for protein
Ask her to come back the next week to confirm that the BP is still elevated
Ask about headache, visual disturbances, dizziness, nausea and upper abdominal pain
Terminate her pregnancy with no delay

questions.question: You should keep systolic blood pressure below?
questions.description: You should keep systolic blood pressure below 160.

questions.question: Which of the following can be used to treat hypertension?

questions.question: Which of the following can be used for the IV treatment of hypertension?
questions.description: Hydralazine can be used for the IV treatment of hypertension.

questions.question: Magnesium Sulphate is used for?

answers.value: Lowering loss of protein in the urine

questions.question: How can you try to prevent seizures in a woman with severe preeclampsia?
questions.description:
To prevent seizures in a woman with severe preeclampsia, you can try the following:

Magnesium Sulphate.

Terminate pregnancy.

answers.value: Let her rest in a silent and dark room

questions.question: Why must you never give IV fluids faster than 1 L in 12 hours in a preeclamptic woman?

She can die from pulmonary oedema

questions.question: In case of severe pre-eclampsia and eclampsia, what should be measured every half hour?
questions.description:
In case of severe pre-eclampsia and eclampsia, the following should be measured every half hour:

Respiratory rate and blood pressure.

Tendon reflexes.

Foetal heart rate.

questions.question: What is the correct loading dose of Magnesium Sulphate?
questions.description: The correct loading dose of Magnesium Sulphate is 4 grams IV.

questions.description: True, Magnesium Sulphate can cause heart arrest.

questions.question: What are signs of intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate?
questions.description:
Signs of intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate are:

Loss of tendon reflexes.

Respiratory depression and/or heart arrest.

questions.question: When should you NOT give a Magnesium Sulphate maintenance dose?
questions.description:
You should NOT give a Magnesium Sulphate maintenance dose in case of:

Loss of tendon reflexes or heart arrest.

Urine output less than 25-30 ml/hour.

Respiratory depression.

answers.value: Loss of tendon reflexes or heart arrest

questions.question: In case of eclampsia at peripheral level, what would you do?
questions.description: In case of eclampsia at peripheral level, you stabilise the woman and refer.

answers.value: Refer immediately and stabilise at higher level facility

questions.question: How would you manage eclamptic fits between gestational weeks 24-34?
questions.description:
You manage eclamptic fits between gestational weeks 24-34 in the following way:

Steroids for foetal lung maturation.

Control BP.

Give Magnesium Sulphate.

questions.question: Is proteinuria a severe feature for Preeclampsia?
questions.description: No, proteinuria is not a severe feature for Preeclampsia.

questions.question: A pregnant woman with no proteinuria has a BP of 170/90. She has?
questions.description: A pregnant woman with no proteinuria has a BP of 170/90. She has severe preeclampsia.

questions.question: Preeclampsia is often cured by itself during pregnancy. True or false?
questions.description: False, preeclampsia is not often cured by itself during pregnancy.

questions.question: What is the final cure for preeclampsia?
questions.description: The final cure for preeclampsia is termination of pregnancy.

questions.question: What is the most frequent cause of maternal death due to preeclampsia?
questions.description: The most frequent cause of maternal death due to preeclampsia is cerebral haemorrhage due to systolic hypertension.

answers.value: Cerebral haemorrhage due to systolic hypertension

questions.question: To prevent maternal death from preeclampsia the single most important action is to?
questions.description: To prevent maternal death from preeclampsia the single most important action is to keep systolic BP below 160.

answers.value: Give two litres of IV fluids FAST

questions.question: In case of eclampsia; in what order would you do the following actions?
questions.description:
In case of eclampsia; you should do the following actions:

1. Call for help and prevent the woman from trauma and tilt her to one side.

2. Give magnesium sulphate IV and manage hypertension.

3. Put in a urine catheter and write down output each hour. 

4. Monitor each half hour and plan delivery.

answers.value: Call for help and prevent the woman from trauma and tilt her to one side
Give magnesium sulphate IV and manage hypertension
Put in a urine catheter and write down output each hour
Monitor each half hour and plan delivery

questions.question: Why is it important to monitor the input and output of fluids?
questions.description:
It is important to monitor the input and output of fluids, because:

Overloading fluids can cause pulmonary oedema.

Oliguria increases the risk of Magnesium Sulphate intoxication.

answers.value: Overloading fluids can cause pulmonary oedema
Oliguria increases the risk of Magnesium Sulphate intoxication

questions.question: What is the antidote to Magnesium Sulphate?
questions.description: The antidote to Magnesium Sulphate is Calcium Gluconate.

chapters.content:
Do not refer if emergency is not controlled!

Never refer a patient with uncontrolled bleeding, retained placenta, uncontrolled hypertension, unevacuated septic or haemorrhagic abortion or septic shock.

Remove placenta by trained provider.

In cases of prolonged labour:
- If at a peripheral facility, refer the woman to a higher centre with her partograph for further management.

- At a referral facility, amniotomy may be done (also for HIV+ women if on antiretroviral therapy). Reassess in 2 hours and decide on further management if there is insufficient progress.

After emergency management and when in a stable condition, discuss decision of referral with woman and relatives.

Quickly organise transport and possible financial aid.

Inform the referral center.

Accompany the woman.

It is crucial that she is accompanied by a health worker who is trained in delivery care and able to manage an emergency situation, if it recurrs during transport.

Consider to bring a relative who can donate blood.

Bring

Referral note.

Essential emergency drugs:

  • Oxytocin and Ergometrine (alternatively Misoprostol) for treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
  • Oxytocin for IM injection immediately postpartum
  • Hydralazine for IV treatment of elevated blood pressure
  • Magnesium Sulphate for eclampsia
  • Calcium Gluconate for intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate
  • Ampicillin for infections
  • Diazepam for pain relief

Supplies:

  • Delivery set
  • Towels
  • IV-equipment + IV fluids
  • Foetoscope or Doppler
  • Blood pressure monitor
  • Ambu bag
  • Suction bulb

During Transport

Observe vital signs and level of consciousness.

If pregnant check FHR.

In case of excessive vaginal bleeding apply bimanual compression.

If the bleeding does not stop apply aorta compression (can be maintained up to 6 hours).

If the woman’s condition permits:

Keep record of all IV fluids, medications given, time of administration and the woman´s condition.

If in labour during transport:

FHR every half an hour.

If pushing and superficial breathing is not enough to repress this urge, stop the transport and deliver the woman.

drugDetails.content:
Indications and Usage

For prophylaxis of ophthalmia neonatorum due to N. gonorrhoeae or C. trachomatis.

Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) including gonorrhea and chlamydia are a main cause of newborn eye infections (the newborn can get transmitted during delivery).

These infections can cause blindness if not treated.

Give antibiotic eye drops or ointment (e.g. Erythromycin Ophtalmic Ointment) to the newborn to prevent eye infections.

Dosage and Administration

For prophylaxis of neonatal gonococcal or chlamydial ophthalmia, a ribbon of ointment approximately 1 cm in length should be instilled into each lower conjunctival sac.

The ointment should not be flushed from the eye following instillation.

A new tube should be used for each infant.

For treatment of eye infection:

Do the following 6-8 times daily:

  • Wash hands with clean water and soap.
  • Wet clean cloth with boiled and cooled water.
  • Use the wet cloth to gently wash off pus from the baby’s eyes.
  • Apply 1% tetracycline eye ointment in each eye 3 times daily.
  • Wash hands.

Contraindications

None

Adverse Reactions

The most frequently reported adverse reactions are minor ocular irritations, redness and hypersensitivity reactions.

Indications and Usage

Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin E1.

Misoprostol is indicated to produce uterine contractions during the third stage of labor and to control postpartum bleeding or haemorrhage.

Dosage and Administration

For preventing post partum haemorrhage:

600 micrograms (3 tablets) sublingually.

For treatment of post partum haemorrhage:

800 micrograms (4 tablets) sublingually.

Repeat 200-800 mcg.

Maximum dose: 1600 mcg.

Contraindications

Prostaglandin allergy. Prostaglandins should not be given to pregnant women as they cause abortion.

Adverse reactions

One out of three treated with misoprostol will have diarrhea or abdominal pain.

It is also common to see a non-allergic rash.

A few percent will experience a transient moderate increase in temperature.

Some will have nausea, vomiting, constipation or flatulence.

Less common headache and dizziness is experienced.

Rarely misoprostol can cause liver affection.

Indications and usage

Oxytocin is a pituitary gland hormone.

Oxytocin injection is indicated to produce uterine contractions during the third stage of labor and to control postpartum haemorrhage.

Dosage and administration

Prevention of postpartum haemorrhage (for all women who have delivered):

10 units (1 ml.) of Oxytocin given intramuscularly immediately after delivery of the baby.

Treatment of postpartum haemorrhage:

20 units of Oxytocin added to 1 litre intravenous fluid (normal saline or Ringer’s lactate) given at fastest flow rate possible.

Continuing IV. dose:

Infuse 20 units of Oxytocin in 1 L. IV. fluids at 40 drops per minute.

Maximum dose:

Not more than 3 L of IV fluids containing Oxytocin.

Oxytocin is temperature sensitive and loses effectiveness after three months of storage at temperatures higher than 30 degrees Celsius (86 degrees Fahrenheit).

Store Oxytocin at a temperature between 2 and 8°C.

Contraindications

Hypersensitivity to Oxytocin.

Do not give Oxytocin as an IV bolus.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are cardiac arrhythmia, nausea, and vomiting.

Rare complications are severe water intoxication which can lead to convulsions and coma and even death, anaphylactic reaction and the loss of clotting factors (fibrinogen) in the blood leading to bleeding complications.

Indications and Usage

Prevents bleeding complications in the newborn.

Dosage and Administration

1 mg given intramuscularly once, directly after birth, to all newborns.

Contraindications

None.

questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/maternal_surface_of_placenta
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/examine_the_placenta
questions.description: You look for missing tissue on the maternal surface of the placenta.

questions.question: 15 minutes after birth you can leave the mother and newborn if everything appears normal. True or False?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/observe_the_mother_and_newborn
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description: False. Do not leave mother and newborn unattended within the first hour after delivery of the placenta.

questions.question: Where and how should the newborn be placed after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/newborn_on_a_blanket
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description: The newborn should be placed with skin to skin with the mother, covered with dry towel and a hat.

answers.value: Skin to skin with the mother, covered with dry towel and a hat
In a baby bed covered with a hat
With the family, the mother needs to rest

questions.question: What should you check for when assessing the mother every 15 minutes after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/observe_the_mother_and_newborn
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description:
When assessing the mother every 15 minutes after birth  you check:

That the uterus is well contracted.

The BP, pulse and that the mother is in a stable condition.

That there is no excessive bleeding.

answers.value: That the uterus is well contracted
The BP, pulse and that the mother is in a stable condition
That there is no excessive bleeding
That she can walk without support

questions.question: How often should you check the mother’s condition after birth if everything appears normal?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/palpation_of_uterus
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description: You should check the mother’s condition every 15 minutes for the first hour after birth if everything appears normal.

answers.value: Every 5 minutes for the first hour
Every 10 minutes for the first hour
Every 15 minutes for the first hour

questions.question: How often should you check the newborn’s condition after birth if everything appears normal?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/observe_the_mother_and_newborn
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description: You check the newborn’s condition every 15 minutes for the first hour after birth if everything appears normal.

answers.value: Every 5 minutes for the first hour
Every 10 minutes for the first hour
Every 15 minutes for the first hour

questions.question: What should you check when assessing the newborn every 15 minutes after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/breastfeeding_child_and_midwife
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description:
When assessing the newborn every 15 minutes after birth you check:

That it is breathing well and has a good colour.

Tone and heart rate.

That it is kept warm and is breastfeeding well

answers.value: That it is breathing well and has a good colour
That it is kept warm and is breastfeeding well

questions.question: After the first hour of observation of the cord what should you do with the cord?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/cord_care_after_1_hour
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description: After the first hour of observation of the cord you should leave the cord uncovered to make it air-dry.

answers.value: Cover the cord with bandage or a patch
Leave the cord uncovered to make it air-dry
Apply herbs according to local tradition

questions.question: What should you give the newborn after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/newborn_on_a_blanket
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description:
After birth you give the newborn:

Antibiotic eye drops.

Vitamin K.

questions.question: Why is early breastfeeding important for the newborn?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/breastfeeding
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description:
Early breastfeeding is important for the newborn because:

It helps the newborn to fully inflate the lungs.

It provides important nutrition to the newborn.

It strengthens the newborn’s immune system.

answers.value: It helps the newborn to fully inflate the lungs
It provides important nutrition to the newborn
It prepares the newborn for bottle feeding
It strengthens the newborn’s immune system

questions.question: Why is early breastfeeding important for the mother?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/breastfeeding
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description: Early breastfeeding important for the mother because it stimulates the uterus to contract.

answers.value: It stimulates the uterus to contract
It strengthens the mother’s immune system
It protects her from getting pregnant again

questions.question: How do you deliver the membranes following the placenta in the best way?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/placenta_in_uterus
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: You deliver the membranes following the placenta in the best way by continuously rotating the placenta, so the membranes become like a rope.

answers.value: By continuously rotating the placenta, so the membranes become like a rope
By quick little pulls so the membranes separate gradually from the uterine wall

questions.question: What is true regarding blood loss?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/vaginal_bleeding
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: Regarding blood loss it is true that you tend to underestimate the blood loss, because the amount looks smaller than it really is.

answers.value: You tend to underestimate the blood loss, because the amount looks smaller than it really is
You tend to overestimate the blood loss, because it is mixed with amniotic fluid and maybe urine
